# How Index Funds And ETFs Cost You More Than You ThinkNative ContentSafeFrame ContainerSafeFrame ContainerNTV ArticleSafeFrame ContainerNTV ArticleSafeFrame ContainerNTV ArticlereCAPTCHAWhy Jack Bogle Doesn't Like ETFs | Forbes

![The Macy's Inc. logo is displayed on a monitor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York,... [+] U.S., on Monday, Feb.

logo is displayed on a monitor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York,... [+] U.S., on Monday, Feb. 22, 2016. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg](https://imageio.forbes.com/specials-images/dam/imageserve/38600218/960x0.

forbes.com/specials-images/dam/imageserve/38600218/960x0.jpg?format=jpg&width=1440)

Index funds & [ETFs](http://www.forbes.com/etfs/) have surged in popularity over the last few years as investors have pulled billions from actively managed mutual or hedge funds and moved their money into more passively managed funds.

Most actively managed funds don't wind up beating the market over the long-term since their total return includes higher expense ratios and other fees, like marketing costs and manager's salaries.

The appeal of index funds or ETFs are their low fees, which are usually less than 1%, and instant and easy diversification.

The appeal of index funds or ETFs are their low fees, which are usually less than 1%, and instant and easy diversification.

### Index funds can yield average returns

Index funds offer investors a chance to own a fund with the specific objective of mimicking an index (like the S&P 500 or the Russell 2000).

So, if you can't beat 'em, maybe you should join 'em, right?

So, if you can't beat 'em, maybe you should join 'em, right? Not so fast.

[After all, average is merely average. You'll never outperform the market if you're just trying to keep pace with it.](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.

](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.com%2Fsites%2Fkarlkaufman%2F2017%2F12%2F12%2Fhow-index-funds-and-etfs-cost-you-more-than-you-think%2F&text=After%20all%2C%20average%20is%20merely%20average.

%20You%27ll%20never%20outperform%20the%20market%20if%20you%27re%20just%20trying%20to%20keep%20pace%20with%20it.)

Sometimes, the most expensive investment is the one you don't make.

)

Sometimes, the most expensive investment is the one you don't make. An important factor to consider when analyzing any investment is the opportunity cost - the cost of not [investing](http://www.forbes.com/investing/) in something else that could net you far greater returns.

### Buying the market can be dangerous

If you're invested in the whole market, you're exposed to market risk; when the market as a whole goes down, so does your investment.

With so much money pouring into index funds, there's a real danger that any kind of severe market sell-off would be exacerbated as panicked investors sell their funds into the drop. This could worsen and prolong any effects a sell-off may have.

This could worsen and prolong any effects a sell-off may have.

One way to alleviate market risk is to invest in stocks with low betas and high dividend yields as a defensive strategy. Beta is a way of measuring the risk of an individual stock. The S&P 500 is the standard and has a beta of 1.

The S&P 500 is the standard and has a beta of 1. Every stock is then given a beta based on how risky it is compared to the S&P, with a lower beta being a less risky investment.

For example, [McDonald's](https://www.forbes.com/companies/mcdonalds/) has a beta of 0.78.
If the market goes down 1%, McDonald's likely will only go down 0.78%.

If the market goes down 1%, McDonald's likely will only go down 0.78%.

Why Jack Bogle Doesn't Like ETFs | Forbes - YouTube

### Relying on sectors is not good diversification

An ETF might track a sector, such as biotech or financials, or even stocks based in a certain country, like the iShares [MSCI](https://www.forbes.com/companies/msci/) Israel Capped ETF.

Many investors are drawn to ETFs in order to easily diversify their portfolio into different sectors.

Sector diversification has its drawbacks, however. Several times throughout the year, active portfolio managers engage in sector rotation. Sometimes they'll need to maintain the weightings in their funds based on their prospectus or philosophy.

Sometimes they'll need to maintain the weightings in their funds based on their prospectus or philosophy. If you're invested in a biotech ETF and the biotech sector suddenly starts selling off due to an untimely rotation, you're not going to be happy with the results.

Betterment, Wealthfront and other popular robo-advisors use algorithms to invest in ETFs.

Betterment, Wealthfront and other popular robo-advisors use algorithms to invest in ETFs. These algorithms are susceptible to trading halts, where you wouldn't be able to sell your investment on extremely volatile days. During the volatility following the Brexit vote last year, Betterment [halted trading on its platform without notifying their customers.

During the volatility following the Brexit vote last year, Betterment [halted trading on its platform without notifying their customers.](https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-robo-adviser-betterment-halted-trade-amid-brexit-panic-2016-06-30) Customers interested in picking up more shares at a discounted price due to a market overreaction were out of luck.

### Investing in the whole market compromises your returns

When you invest in an index fund, you're investing in every stock in that index and you may not be getting some stocks at their best price. A stock may have recently experienced a huge run-up in price and may be considered overvalued at the time you buy shares in an index fund.

A stock may have recently experienced a huge run-up in price and may be considered overvalued at the time you buy shares in an index fund.

You're not only getting the best performers, you're also investing in the so-called "dogs" of the index, which drag down your total returns.

By buying an S&P 500 index fund, you'd be buying stocks like [Macy's](https://www.forbes.com/companies/macys/) and other retail companies, which have been hit hard by the "Amazon effect." Macy's is down around 25% this year (at the time of this writing).

Macy's is down around 25% this year (at the time of this writing).

### Don't be average...or lazy

As a portion of a long-term portfolio, it may be fine to allot a certain amount to index funds or ETFs. Some people just may not have the time to actively manage their investments.

Some people just may not have the time to actively manage their investments.

Index funds offer low fees and passive management that will net you average returns, but you'll never beat the market. When the market takes a dive, so do your returns.

Robo-advisors like Betterment are fine for lazy investors who are generally uninterested in following the market, but the lack of control is a major drawback for more active investors.

Bottom line, if beating the market is a goal of yours, it's a far better idea to pick a select few stocks and actively manage your own portfolio. You'll be able to buy and sell whenever you want and can diversify based on your own investing philosophy.

## The Futility of Forecasting

## The Futility of Forecasting

We get suckered at the end of every year. Headlines and cover stories announce: “2024 Market Outlook,” “2024 S&P Forecast,” “Stock Market Predictions for 2024.”

Why do we, the investing public, still heed these prognostications?

It may be our desire for predictability in a world that is anything but orderly. We want to believe someone can guide us through the foggy future and are willing to pay for that certainty.

Yet, no one can foresee the future. It doesn’t matter how smart you are or how well-trained your predictive models are.

Yet, no one can foresee the future. It doesn’t matter how smart you are or how well-trained your predictive models are. Just remember this: in December 2021, 400 PhDs at the Federal Reserve predicted interest rates would be around 1.75% in 2023. Rates are now over 5%.

Rates are now over 5%.

The global economy is a beast of a different nature. It's influenced by countless variables—political events, natural disasters, technological breakthroughs. Trying to forecast market movements in such an environment is like predicting the path of a leaf blowing in a hurricane.

What's the harm in these off-the-mark predictions?

What's the harm in these off-the-mark predictions? For starters, they lead to misguided investment decisions. Investors, especially the less experienced ones, might take these forecasts as gospel, making moves that could hurt their portfolios in the long run.

Investors, especially the less experienced ones, might take these forecasts as gospel, making moves that could hurt their portfolios in the long run.

Investors who followed bearish Wall Street calls at the end of 2022 left a lot of cash on the sidelines as the S&P rallied over 20% this year.

## Protect, Don't Predict: A Strategy for Individual Investors

So, what should individual investors do? The answer lies in a simple yet powerful strategy: Protect, Don't Predict.

Prioritize timeless investing strategies over trying to outguess the market's next moves. This way, you’ll limit your downside risk while still enjoying the positive momentum of a bull market.

This way, you’ll limit your downside risk while still enjoying the positive momentum of a bull market. Here’s how:

*   **Buy Quality Stocks:** Companies with strong balance sheets, solid management, and a history of growing dividend payments are reliable options in any economy and are built to withstand tough times.

Find companies that are leaders in their respective industries and have the best chance to stay in that position.
*   **Set Up an Emergency Fund:** A simple solution that many ignore. Maintain a percentage of your wealth in a conservative account with low-risk assets or money market funds.

Maintain a percentage of your wealth in a conservative account with low-risk assets or money market funds. This way, you’ll avoid getting caught in a position where you’re forced to sell investments at an inopportune time.
*   **Keep a Long-Term Focus:** A long-term perspective will help weather day-to-day market volatility.

*   **Keep a Long-Term Focus:** A long-term perspective will help weather day-to-day market volatility. Panic selling and emotional reactions to news are the enemies of long-term success in the stock market.
*   **Stay Informed:** Keep current with the news in a way that works for you.

*   **Stay Informed:** Keep current with the news in a way that works for you. Read up on the market and use that knowledge to make wiser investing decisions.
*   **Trust Your Instincts:** Don’t underestimate your own investing instincts. They’re honed from your daily experiences and what you read or watch in the news.

They’re honed from your daily experiences and what you read or watch in the news. Thinking critically and deeply may be more valuable than any analyst’s predictive modeling.

Investors can navigate the market's uncertainties more effectively by focusing on protection strategies.

Investors can navigate the market's uncertainties more effectively by focusing on protection strategies. This approach may not be as flashy as predicting the next big market move, but it's a more sustainable and less stressful way to manage your investments.

This approach may not be as flashy as predicting the next big market move, but it's a more sustainable and less stressful way to manage your investments.

## Embrace the Market’s Uncertainty

Lou Reed wrote, “Life’s like Sanskrit read to a pony,” a humorous sentiment investors should remember while navigating through the fog of Wall Street’s inscrutable forecasts.

As a savvy investor, it's essential to question popular narratives, focus on informed decision-making and trust your common sense instead of complex models.

After all, the only certainty in the market is its uncertainty.

Richard didn’t subscribe to any one particular philosophy on investing. Instead, he approached the market like the scientist he was trained to be, concocting his own amalgamation until he found the right balance that worked for him.

This Father’s Day I’m sharing the best investing lessons I learned from my dad, starting with his motto:

**“NO ONE LOVES YOUR MONEY MORE THAN YOU”**

Many people hand their money to a financial advisor or buy mutual funds, only reviewing quarterly statements to see how they’ve done over the last few months.

Richard believed it was essential to maintain control over his portfolio, as no fund manager or financial advisor would care about his money more than he did. He achieved astounding results without paying any fees other than trading commissions.

A retail investor has no control over how a mutual or hedge fund invests their money. They have to pay fees, which weigh down performance.

They have to pay fees, which weigh down performance. Additional fees are often charged for withdrawing money, even if performance is not up to expectations and the investor wants to switch to a different fund. As an individual investor, Richard had flexibility to construct whatever portfolio he wanted, without fees.

The internet has leveled the playing field for individual investors.

As an individual investor, Richard had flexibility to construct whatever portfolio he wanted, without fees.

The internet has leveled the playing field for individual investors. There’s more transparency in the market and there’s access to more information than ever before. An enterprising investor, with enough time to devote to research and portfolio management, can do very well and grow their wealth, just like my father did.

**“BE INFORMED AND ‘INVEST IN WHAT YOU KNOW’”**

Richard spent a good portion of his day reading, watching CNBC and accumulating knowledge. He subscribed to many different newsletters and magazines: Barron’s, Morningstar, the Wall Street Journal and Forbes, to name a few. His bookshelf was filled with books by Warren Buffett, Benjamin Graham and Peter Lynch.

His bookshelf was filled with books by Warren Buffett, Benjamin Graham and Peter Lynch.

He wanted to know what the professionals were saying about the market while discovering new ideas and investment opportunities. His advice to me was to be discerning about that information while doing my own research.

Like Warren Buffett and Peter Lynch, Richard would look for companies with a business model he could understand.

Like Warren Buffett and Peter Lynch, Richard would look for companies with a business model he could understand. He especially liked companies with a large economic moat, which gave them a strong advantage over their competitors.

After studying the financials and doing whatever market research he could, he’d build a position in the stock slowly and accumulate more shares over the long term with small, incremental buys.

Instead of going all in right away, he’d wait to see if the reasons behind his interest in the stock were correct. If he was right, the stock would go up and he’d continue to add to the position. If he realized he was wrong or the story surrounding the stock changed, he’d accept that and sell out without losing too much money.

One of my dad’s favorite sayings was “earnings are opinion; cash is a fact.”

Revenue and earnings get all the attention, but the first place we’d look when analyzing an investment is the company’s free cash flow.

Free cash flow, though, is hard to hide and very useful to shareholders. If a company is growing free cash flow over time, management has more opportunity to buy back shares or give that cash back to shareholders via dividends.

**“DIVIDENDS ARE YOUR FRIENDS”**

Dividends are steady paychecks from companies that you don’t have to work for and, if they’re qualified dividends, are taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income.

Richard used dividend payments to generate cash flow within his portfolio. He’d accumulate that cash and patiently hold on to it, waiting until he spotted temporary dips in the market so he could buy on weakness.

When we discovered a company with a culture where the dividend is sacrosanct and there were long-term growth opportunities in the share price, we knew we’d found a wonderful stock.

**“DON’T FALL IN LOVE WITH A STOCK”**

The hardest lesson to put into practice was learning to control my emotions when investing. My dad applied an analytical mindset to the stocks in his portfolio and tried as best he could to approach his investments with cold logic and a clear-headed view.

It was incredible to watch him operate. One day, he sold all his shares of a company that he’d been building a position in for several years. A headline came across the wire that the company admitted to an accounting irregularity and the stock was plummeting. “Sell everything,” he said.

“Sell everything,” he said. “I have no tolerance for fraud.”

“A stock doesn’t know that you own it, so don’t fall in love with any,” he’d tell me. “You can’t take investing personally.”

“When you sell a stock at a loss,” he said, “you’ve admitted that you’ve made a mistake.

Most people can’t bear to admit they’re wrong, so they hold on, hoping to get their money back. The stock then continues to sink and they lose more.

“If you can accept that you were wrong, you can learn your lesson, move on and find a better use of your cash.”

He took the same approach when a stock was on its way up.

If he sold some shares and the stock kept rising, he wouldn’t kick himself. Instead, he’d quote Baron Rothschild: “I made my fortune by selling too early.”

“Don’t get too excited when you win,” my dad would say, “or too upset when you lose.”

Throughout the last few months of his life, I’d visit with my dad and we’d discuss the market and various strategies for the portfolio.

I’d visit with my dad and we’d discuss the market and various strategies for the portfolio. His health was failing and I knew he was struggling, but seeing me share his passion for investing caused his dimming eyes to spark briefly. As he approached the end, I could differentiate the good days from the bad by whether he wanted to watch CNBC or if he showed little interest in the trading day.

My dad died on a Friday morning, surrounded by his family. Later that day, after funeral arrangements were finalized, I placed a trade in tribute right before the market closed, buying shares in the company he spent most of his career with and whose stock helped him grow rich.

Every Monday morning now, when the market opens, I hear him in my head saying “TGIM.” Whenever I’m about to make a trade, I imagine a conversation between us, discussing the reasoning behind the trade.

It’s true that “you can’t take it with you,” but my dad left behind a lasting legacy in the lessons he taught me about investing.

More importantly, he taught me how to be a great father.

I’ve got a son of my own now and I’ve already set aside money in an account that should grow alongside him. I’m looking forward to the day when we can sit down together and I can teach him everything I’ve learned from my dad.
